|Title=Differentiating between heart failure with reduced EF and heart failure with preserved EF
|Description=Knowing the threshold values for LVEF
|Topic=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Olivier Huttin
|Order=8}}
- The ejection fraction (EF) is the fraction of blood ejected during each systole as a percentage of the end-diastolic volume (EDV).

- Left ventricular EF is the parameter most commonly used to characterise left ventricular systolic function.

- It is measured by echocardiography (Figure 1).


- LVEF measurements can be used to classify 3 main types of heart failure:

o CI with reduced LVEF if LVEF ≤ 40%.

o CI with preserved LVEF if LVEF ≥ 50%.

o CI with moderately impaired LVEF if between 41% and 49%.


- The difference between these two mechanisms has therapeutic implications, as the majority of mortality-reducing treatments for heart failure currently target heart failure with reduced LVEF.

properties.question: What is the primary difference between heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)?
properties.option_a: HFrEF is characterized by a higher LVEF, while HFpEF has a lower LVEF.
properties.option_b: HFrEF is typically diagnosed in patients with a higher body mass index (BMI), while HFpEF is more common in patients with a lower BMI.
properties.option_c: HFrEF is often associated with a higher risk of arrhythmias, while HFpEF is more commonly linked to cognitive decline.
properties.option_d: HFrEF is typically diagnosed in patients with a history of coronary artery disease, while HFpEF is more common in patients with a history of hypertension.
